column13:
Amateur. Unintuitive. Odd choices of information to display and ways to display it (i.e some very in depth system output - but just dumped straight out). 

Very difficult to approach it with the idea 'I want to do X' and see immediately how to do it. Far, far too many free form text boxes for complicated syntax entering. Not obvious what you're meant to put in nor what format it should be in even if you know what it will translate to under the tin (nfs config I'm looking at you)
column21:
I did a plugin in unmenu. Has to be 'approved' by joel (?) before it can make it in there formally. Not an obvious process.

Feels like we're heavily reinventing the wheel (slackware already has a package management system yet here we are manually rolling our own packages on top..) and no proper central package repository.

Were this RedHat (or equivalent) or Ubuntu it would seem clear we would push for a community yum repo or ppa though who and how that would be stewarded would be a sticking point.

Slackware, I believe (not as familiar) has analogous repo / package maintenance systems. I don't know why we're not using them (actually I can guess, but it's probably not for discussion here ;) ).
column22:
Honestly? Not an interface one really.

Stop (or make it optional) unraid being it's own distro. Port / maintain it for a more common distribution(s) and provide a yum / ppa to install it (emhttp and a kernel module) on any old machine. Let the distros do the heavy work of the packages and fluff around the unraid core instead of spending most of the time battling that in development and retreading it all.

I can understand why that would be difficult and why having it as an 'appliance' is beneficial but it feels like it's being dragged down under it's own weight right now.

So a middle ground, as above - having as part of the core a maintained package management system which we can have a community repo spun off from. Not a homebrewed one preferably a 'standard' one that is widely used already in slackware.

slapt-get? sbopkg? not sure if any of them would do it.

unmenu comes close but it's not true package management / reinvents the wheel / the gatekeepers are..well...

column12: Checking status. Occasional config changes.
column13: No plugin manager. Weird confirmation checkboxes. I don't like that parity checks correct errors by default. Emhttp needs to become a service daemon or something -- it shouldn't be serving up the web interface.
column22:
Good UPS support. Notification support. Automatic parity checks (not corrections). Consistent, sensible plugin framework with a list of curated plugins. The current plugin ecosystem is a mess. The UI needs to be fast. I like the m0n0wall/pfSense/FreeNAS series of web interfaces. Perhaps some wizards for common drive swap operations (upgrade parity, swap two drives, etc) -- I shouldn't have to dig up recipes in the wiki or forum.

Unrelated to the interface: It's ridiculous that unRaid doesn't include ssh by default. Telnet has been deprecated for more than a decade. I would like a second parity drive. I want a filesystem with built-in integrity checking (Btrfs, ZFS) -- if there's a bit error, how do you know if it's the parity or the data that's bad. Support drive upgrade paths that don't require blowing away parity or just trusting it. Upgrade unRaid from the UI. Opt-in automatic error reporting (?).

Perhaps some of these suggestions should be forwarded on to Tom.

column13:
Mostly using the simple features extension. When it crashes there is no simple way to do a clean shutdown of the server.

The quick log is somewhat short and when using the syslog utility the refresh always kicks you to the top of the page (on firefox - didn't test other browsers) making it unusable.
column14: No, but I would like to
column21: Documentation on what is possible with the gui and how to achieve it is nearly inexistant. Only way is to learn by looking on other plugins.
column22:
The sleep function is rather flaky. Thats sad, as it is a must have for me. (Though more of a core unraid feature and no gui problem.)

The idea to include the preclear into simplefeatures was nice, though it would have been better to include JoeL in the process instead of just using his code.

Mounted drives (I have an appdrive mounted outside the array) should not be available for preclear.

WebGui source should be available on github so it is easier for users to help fixing problems, if there are any.

column7: Free space, temperature, green status indicators, spinup status
column12:
Checking for errors in syslog. (I use unMENU which highlights errors in orange/red so that I can quickly see any problems)

Checking UPS status - via unmenu & apcupsd. (Battery health, charge, time since last switchover to battery, estimated running time on battery at current load)
column13:
Extremely complicated to use. Don't know where things are. Very poor user experience - repetitive tasks are too long. E.g. deleting users requires opening each user, ticking delete, confirming and reloading page.

Setting disks not to be visible via SMB is horrible. Need to click on each disk, set security level (meaning of security levels is not clear - Public, Secure, Private) save.

Not clear that configuration is done from the homescreen. Looks like a status page. Did not expect to make config changes from it.

Total free space is not shown.

No visible validation on creating users - tried to create users but wasn't working. Only discovered a problem when I connected a monitor to the server where I discovered errors printed to the terminal.
column22:
A notifications framework where I can set up multiple notification channels and have configurable alerts sent to each. Ideally would be like the Sickbeard notifications page (if you've seen it)

Extensible support for emails and other alert systems especially Pushover/Growl etc.

PS I understand that only so much can be done from an admin tool. I'd be really interested to see the results of this survey posted on the forum. Especially the biggest pain points etc. I expect there will be some consistency across complaints which might prompt action from Tom/Limetech to improve.

column22:
I'm happy to have a nicer-looking GUI, but not at the cost of bloat - the whole reason I like unRAID is that it's nice, simple and uncluttered with a small footprint. I don't use plugins much (I use unRAID for safe storage, not as a server for anything else), and it spends most of its time asleep.
I don't want to have to add whole rafts of dependencies and packages just to get a nice-looking front-end - I'd rather the low-fat version ;-)

column12:
Looking at main page, temps, disks spun down...
Stopping, starting, updating plugins
column13: Inconsistencies amongst sections. The entire plugin system because they are individual projects with no standard. For example some are easy to update via web, whereas other need to telnet into...having to use simplefeatures' extra features, when really they should be in stock. No progression in a very long time. The webgui is the face of the OS, it needs redoing with a good framework that is expandable. New users are put off by what is in actual fact a very simple end user experience by the archaic nature in which it presents itself. Unraid is much more than just a nas solution...plugins are its future.
column22: Total overhaul of the user experience, the webgui... We live in a media enriched world where great program's are bing written for Linux all the time. I want to be able to manage all my plugins in the same way...I should be able to download, install and update all from the same tab. I shouldn't have to care about dependencies, plugin plgs, not being hosted by their author anymore....simply anyone should be able to use the webgui, and for power users, they can still use the command line. Every house should have a home server for all their content and it should be able to be administered by a mum. Logs...for the love of god, all logs should be accessible in the GUI next to it's respective plugin and be able to download directly from the web, for whatever troubleshooting in the forums...a link to the forums...system temps (CPU/motherboard) visible...scheduled automatic parity checks...folder area, so that if someone comes over, can plug in a hdd, it is recognised and can copy files to it...realtime system monitor...ability to update unraid itself...hdd health check monitoring and alerts...critical system messages notifier by email/twitter etc......a unicorn :)

column12: Mostly for checking the status of my drives (temps, errors, spinning status, activity, free space) but other than that it's for administrative purposes and setting up the system, but I've only really done that one time.
column13: Actually it works well for my purposes since I don't use it heavily. It looks a bit dated and is a bit clunky to use, though.
column22: I'm a big fan of self-chosen automated updates, that does the updates quickly and simply at the press of a button. If anything, I'd really like to throw that in... an option to check for automatic updates for all the installed plugins you run (and the unRaid server itself if it is at all possible) so that I could at a glance on the main screen see when there are new versions available to update to, check the possible change notes and then be able to run those updates quickly if I wanted to.
